title: 5 best new restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston (Feb. 5, 2026)
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Nohri introduces Nikkei cuisine with handrolls and ceviches at 5 Tyler St., Chinatown, now open January 2026.
Novo Lantern replaces Nan Xiang Express, offering handmade dumplings and noodle dishes at 1750 Washington St., South End.
Retro Room opens a listening lounge in Back Bay Social's basement, serving comfort food and cocktails, 867 Boylston St., Back Bay.

title: Super Bowl betting expected to surge as experts warn of problem gambling
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Estimated $1.76 billion expected to be wagered on Super Bowl LX in the U.S., a 27% increase from last year.
Massachusetts reported $98.47 million in taxable sports betting revenue in December 2025, generating $19.6 million in tax revenue.
Problem gambling rates among Massachusetts gamblers rose from 20.9% in 2022 to 28% in 2024, heightening public health concerns.

title: Boston police release Super Bowl safety plan, limiting traffic, parking, pedestrian access
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Boston Police will enforce traffic, parking, and pedestrian restrictions near colleges and nightlife areas during Super Bowl LX.
Parking and vehicle access will be limited around Boston University, Northeastern University, Kenmore Square, and other busy nightlife areas.
Police urge vigilance due to cold weather, with patrols increased near bars and house parties to prevent underage drinking and disruptions.

title: As storm cleanup lingers, City Council pushes for snow melters and dedicated ‘snow corps’
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston City Council proposes snow melters and a volunteer 'snow corps' following complaints after a major winter storm.
Councilor Ed Flynn and others urge Mayor Wu to explore new snow removal strategies due to resource and support concerns.
Boston faces severe transportation impacts from the storm; Councilor Collins seeks state help with ongoing snow removal.

title: Not Drake Maye — just his Raynham, Mass., lookalike
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Tyler Dumas, a 19-year-old from Raynham, resembles Patriots quarterback Drake Maye, gaining viral fame and local celebrity status.
Dumas's resemblance to Maye was first noticed by his aunt during the Patriots' preseason, leading to viral TikTok attention.
Despite the fame, Dumas remains humble, balancing college and work, while enjoying the thrill of being compared to an NFL star.

title: David Pastrnak will be a flag-bearer for Czechia at Winter Olympics opening ceremony
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: David Pastrnak, Bruins winger, will be a flag-bearer for Czechia at the 2026 Milano Cortina Winter Olympics opening ceremony.
Czechia faces off against Canada in their first preliminary round matchup at the Winter Olympics on February 12.
Leon Draisaitl of the Edmonton Oilers will also serve as a flag-bearer, representing Germany in the Olympics.

title: Where were the 2025 Patriots back in 2015? We collected stories from the locker room and podium
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Carlton Davis signed with Auburn on Feb. 4, 2015, after initially committing to Ohio State.
Robert Spillane was a freshman at Western Michigan in 2015, driven by dissatisfaction to succeed in the NFL.
Stefon Diggs declared for the 2015 NFL draft after three seasons at the University of Maryland.

title: After 25 years, MetroWest Jewish Day School will shut its doors
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: MetroWest Jewish Day School in Framingham to close after 25 years due to unsustainable costs of its personalized education model.
Founded in 2003, the school served over 300 students from 30 towns but now only has about 20 students enrolled.
The Finn family will provide tuition support for students transitioning to other Jewish day schools for continued education.

title: Amid setbacks and tragedy, K’Lavon Chaisson’s road has led him to Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: K'Lavon Chaisson, a former first-round pick, has become a key figure in the New England Patriots' defense.
Chaisson faced significant setbacks including his father's violent death and a torn ACL during his football career.
He revived his career with the Patriots in 2025, recording career-high stats and helping the team reach Super Bowl LX.

title: Before and after: In New England, the ‘Ugliest House in America’ gets a makeover
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Vermont home called 'Mishmash Hodgepodge' wins HGTV's 'Ugliest House in America' season 7, earning a $150,000 renovation.
Originally described as a chaotic color-block structure, the 3,344-square-foot home received a total makeover from designer Alison Victoria.
Post-renovation, the home features a new patio, sliding glass doors, and a refreshed exterior, blending with its picturesque surroundings.
